Macau is otherwise known in Chinese as ''Haojing'' ({{lang|zh-hant|濠鏡}}, literally "Moat Mirror") or ''Jinghai'' ({{lang|zh-hant|鏡海}}, literally "Mirror Sea").Macau Yearbook 2007, 517. The name ''Macau'' is thought to be derived from the ''[[A-Ma Temple]]'' ({{zh|t=媽閣廟 |p=Māgé Miào |cy=Māgok Miuh|links=no}}), a temple built in 1448 dedicated to [[Mazu (goddess)|Mazu]], the goddess of seafarers and fishermen.{{cite web|title=Macau A-ma Temple|url=http://www.travelchinaguide.com/attraction/macau/a_ma.htm|website=Travel China Guide|accessdate=8 September 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150906120411/http://www.travelchinaguide.com/attraction/macau/a_ma.htm|archivedate=6 September 2015|df=dmy-all}} More precisely, the name ''Macau'' corresponds to the Chinese name "{{lang|zh-hant|媽港}}" ({{zh|p=Māgǎng|links=no}}), meaning "Mazu Harbor", and referring to the waters adjacent to the Ama Temple.Wu, Z., and G. Jin. "The evolution of spellings of ‘Macau’: An examination of early Portuguese and Western archival materials." Macao–cultural interaction and literary representations (2014): 3-11. == History == {{Main|History of Macau|Portuguese Macau|Transfer of sovereignty over Macau}} [[File:Saopaulo Chinnery.jpg|thumb|left|[[Ruins of St. Paul's]], built in 1602 and destroyed by fire in 1835]] The history of Macau is traced back to the [[Qin dynasty]] (221–206 BC), when the region now called Macau came under the jurisdiction of Panyu County, Nanhai Prefecture (modern [[Guangdong]]). The first recorded Chinese inhabitants of the area were people seeking refuge in Macau from invading [[Mongols]] during the [[Southern Song]].{{cite web |url=http://www.macaudata.com/macauweb/Encyclopedia/html/44907.htm |title=The entry "Macau history" in Macau Encyclopedia |accessdate=2 January 2008 |publisher=Macau Foundation |language=Chinese |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071013210914/http://macaudata.com/macauweb/Encyclopedia/html/44907.htm |archivedate=13 October 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} Under the [[Ming dynasty]] (1368–1644), fishermen migrated to Macau from Guangdong and [[Fujian]]. The Macau native people were [[Tanka people|Tanka]] boat people. Macau did not develop as a major settlement until the Portuguese arrived in the 16th century.Chan, 3–4. In 1513, [[Jorge Álvares]] became the first Portuguese to land in China. In 1535, Portuguese traders obtained the rights to anchor ships in Macau's harbours and to carry out trading activities, though not the right to stay onshore.Fung, 5–6. Around 1552–1553, they obtained temporary permission to erect storage sheds onshore, in order to dry out goods drenched by sea water;Fung, 7. they soon built rudimentary stone houses around the area now called Nam Van. ===Portuguese Macau=== In 1557, the Portuguese [[Luso-Chinese agreement (1554)|established a permanent settlement in Macau]], paying an annual rent of 500 [[tael]]s (18.9 [[kilogram]]s{{\}}41.6 [[Pound (mass)|pounds]]) of silver. The Portuguese continued to pay an annual tribute up to 1863 in order to stay in Macau.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CioAAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA522 |title=Dictionary of dates, and universal reference. [With] |volume= |year=1885 |author=Joseph Timothy Haydn |editor= |publisher= Oxford University|edition=18 |location= |isbn= |page=522 |pages= |quote=MACAO (in Quang-tong, S. China) was given to the Portuguese as a commercial station in 1586 (in return for their assistance against pirates), subject to an annual tribute, which was remitted in 1863. Here Camoens composed part of the "Lusiad."}} By 1564, Portugal commanded western trade with [[India]], [[Japan]], and China. In 1631 the Chinese restricted Portuguese commerce in China to the port of Macau.{{cite book |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=AvRZAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA262 |title=The Mirror of literature, amusement, and instruction, Volume 7 |volume= |year=1845 |author= |editor= |publisher=J. Limbird |edition= |location=London |isbn= |page=262 |pages= |quote=The Chinese were obliged to restrict the commerce of Portugal to the port of Macau, in 1631. A partnership was then formed with some Chinese dealers in Canton, who were to furnish exports and take delivery of imports at Macau. This scheme did not suit the Chinese; they were dissatisfied with their partners, and speedily dissolved the connection.}} (Princeton University). During the 17th century, some 5,000 slaves lived in Macau, in addition to 2,000 Portuguese and 20,000 Chinese.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nPyg0evI8ykC&pg=PA32 |title=The Survival of Empire: Portuguese Trade and Society in China and the South China Sea 1630–1754|year=2004 |author=George Bryan Souza|publisher=Cambridge University Press |edition=reprint|isbn=978-0-521-53135-1 |page=32 |pages= |quote=soldiers 5000 slaves 20000 Chinese 1643 2000 moradores (Portuguese inhabitants) 1644 40000 total inhabitants 1648 Jesuits record}}{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oCx0D0iE2QoC&pg=PA323 |title=Atlas of languages of intercultural communication in the Pacific, Asia and the Americas |year=1996 |author=Stephen Adolphe Wurm|author2=Peter Mühlhäusler|author3=[[Darrell Tryon|Darrell T. Tryon]]|publisher=Walter de Gruyter |edition= |location= |isbn=978-3-11-013417-9 |page=323|quote=The Portuguese population of Macau was never very large. Between the period 1601–1669, a typical cross section of the population consisted of about 600 casados, 100–200 other Portuguese, some 5000 slaves and a growing number of Chinese }}{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LP9q1dzVRYQC&pg=PA63|title=Macau History and Society|year=2011 |author=Zhidong Hao|publisher=Hong Kong University Press |edition=illustrated|isbn=978-988-8028-54-2 |page=63|quote=This is a time when there were most African slaves, about 5100. In comparison there were about 1000 to 2000 during the later Portuguese rule in Macau.}} As more Portuguese settled in Macau to engage in trade, they made demands for self-administration; but this was not achieved until the 1840s.Historical figures of Macau, by CCTV. In 1576, [[Pope Gregory XIII]] established the [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Macau]].{{cite web|url=http://www.macaudata.com/macauweb/Encyclopedia/html/11502.htm |title=The entry "Catholic" in Macau Encyclopedia |publisher=Macau Foundation |accessdate=6 January 2008 |language=Chinese |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071224173753/http://www.macaudata.com/macauweb/Encyclopedia/html/11502.htm |archivedate=24 December 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} In 1583, the Portuguese in Macau were permitted to form a Senate to handle various issues concerning their social and economic affairs under strict supervision of the Chinese authority,Historical figures of Macau by CCTV but there was no transfer of sovereignty. [[File:1870Macao.jpg|thumb|Macau, c. 1870]] Macau prospered as a port, but it was the target of repeated failed attemptsHistory of the Qing ({{lang|zh|清史稿}}){{full citation needed|date=November 2018}} by the [[Netherlands|Dutch]] to gain possession of it across multiple Dutch raids occurring in the early 1600s. The raids on Macau culminated in the [[Battle of Macau]] on 24 June 1622, in which the Portuguese handily repelled the attack. While Dutch raids on Portuguese colonies continued in the coming years, this definitive defeat discouraged any future Dutch attempts to conquer the settlement. The majority of the defenders were African slaves, with only a few Portuguese soldiers and priests. Captain Kornelis Reyerszoon was commander of the 800-strong Dutch invasion force.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Nsh8NHDQHlcC&pg=PA238 |title=Slavery and South Asian history |volume= |year=2006 |editor1=Indrani Chatterjee|editor2=Richard Maxwell Eaton |publisher=Indiana University Press |edition=illustrated |location= |isbn=978-0-253-21873-5 |page=238 |pages= |quote=Portuguese,"he concluded;"The Portuguese beat us off from Macau with their slaves."10 The same year as the Dutch ... an English witness recorded that the Portuguese defense was conducted primarily by their African slaves }}{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vWLRxJEU49EC&pg=PA544 |title=Middle East and Africa |volume= |year=1996 |author= |editor= |publisher=Taylor & Francis |edition= |location= |isbn=978-1-884964-04-6 |page=544 |pages= |quote=A miscellaneous assemblage of Portuguese soldiers, citizens, African slaves, friars, and Jesuits managed to withstand the attack. Following this defeat, the Dutch made no further attempts to take Macau, although they continued to harass }}{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-Gr51C1eS1oC&pg=PA159 |title=Macau: a cultural Janus |volume= |year=1999 |author=Christina Miu Bing Cheng |editor= |publisher=Hong Kong University Press |edition=illustrated |location= |isbn=978-962-209-486-4 |page=159 |pages= |quote=invaded Macau on 24 June 1622 but was defeated by a handful of Portuguese priests, citizens and African slaves }}{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Lw6JYOYgjokC&pg=PA15 |title=Strolling in Macau: A Visitor's Guide to Macau, Taipa, and Coloane |volume= |year=2007 |author=Steven Bailey |editor= |publisher=ThingsAsian Press |edition=illustrated |location= |isbn=978-0-9715940-9-8 |page=15 |pages= |quote=On June 24, 1622, a Dutch fleet under Captain Kornelis Reyerszoon assembled a landing force of some 800 armed sailors, a number thought more than sufficient to overpower Macau's relatively weak garrison. Sono|publisher=HSRC|location= |isbn=978-0-7969-1525-2 |page=23|quote=A year later, Captain Coen was still harping on the same theme: 'The slaves of the Portuguese at Macau served them so well and faithfully, that it was they who defeated and drove away our people there last year'. }}{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/?id=qUAsAAAAMAAJ |title=Fidalgos in the Far East 1550–1770 |volume= |year=1968 |author=Charles Ralph Boxer|publisher=Oxford UP |edition=2nd, illustrated, reprint |location= |isbn= |page=85|quote=The enemy, it was reported, 'had lost many more men than we, albeit mostly slaves. Our people saw very few Portuguese'. A year later he was still harping on the same theme. 'The slaves of the Portuguese at Macau served them so well and faithfully, that it was they who defeated and drove away our people there}} (University of Michigan). Following the [[First Opium War]] (1839–42), Portugal occupied the empty islands of [[Taipa]] and [[Coloane]] in 1851 and 1864 respectively. On 1 December 1887, the [[Qing dynasty|Qing]] and Portuguese governments signed the [[Sino-Portuguese Treaty of Peking]], under which China ceded the right of "perpetual occupation and government of Macao by Portugal" in compliance with the statements of the Protocol of Lisbon. In return, Macau Government would cooperate with Hong Kong's smuggling trade in Indian opium and China would profit from imposing customs taxes. Portugal was also obliged "never to alienate Macau without previous agreement with China", therefore ensuring that negotiation between Portugal and France (regarding a possible exchange of Macau and [[Portuguese Guinea]] with the [[French Congo]]) or with other countries would not go forward – so that the British commercial interests would be secured; Macau officially became a territory under Portuguese administration. In 1928, after the Qing dynasty had been overthrown following the [[Xinhai Revolution]], the [[Kuomintang]] (KMT) government officially notified Portugal that it would abrogate the Treaty of Amity and Commerce;Macau Yearbook 2007, 518. the two powers signed a new Sino-Portuguese Friendship and Trade Treaty in place of the abrogated treaty. Changing only a few provisions concerning tariff principles and matters relating to business affairs, the new treaty did not alter the sovereignty of Macau and Portuguese government of Macau remained unchanged.Fung, 409–410. During [[World War II]], unlike [[Portuguese Timor]], which was occupied by the Japanese in 1942 along with [[West Timor|Dutch Timor]], the Japanese respected Portuguese neutrality in Macau, but only up to a point. Macau enjoyed a brief period of economic prosperity as the only neutral port in [[South China]] after the Japanese had occupied Guangzhou and Hong Kong. In August 1943, Japanese troops seized the British steamer ''Sian'' in Macau and killed about 20 guards. The next month they demanded the installation of Japanese "advisors" under the threat of overt military occupation. The result was that a virtual Japanese [[protectorate]] was created over Macau. [[File:MacauPortoInterior1900.jpg|thumb|left|The "O Porto Interior" in Macau, c. 1900]] When it was discovered that "neutral" Macau was planning to sell aviation fuel to Japan, aircraft from the {{USS|Enterprise|CV-6|6}} bombed and strafed the hangar of the Naval Aviation Centre on 16 January 1945 to destroy the fuel. American air raids on targets in Macau were also made on 25 February and 11 June 1945. Following Portuguese government protests, in 1950 the United States paid US$20,255,952 to the government of Portugal.p. 116 Garrett, Richard J. ''The Defences of Macau: Forts, Ships and Weapons Over 450 Years'' Hong Kong University Press, 1 February 2010 Between the end of the [[Pacific War]] and the establishment of the People's Republic of China, Macau served as a safe haven for refugees of the [[Chinese Civil War]].p.117 Garrett, Richard J. ''The Defences of Macau: Forts, Ships and Weapons Over 450 Years'' Hong Kong University Press, 1 February 2010 After the establishment of the People's Republic of China in 1949, the Beijing government declared the Sino-Portuguese Treaty invalid as an "[[unequal treaty]]" imposed by foreigners on China. However, Beijing was not ready to settle the treaty question, allowing the maintenance of "the status quo" until a more appropriate time.Fung, 410–411. Influenced by the [[Cultural Revolution]] in mainland China and by general dissatisfaction with Portuguese government, riots broke out in Macau in 1966. In the most serious, the so-called [[12-3 incident]], 6 people were killed and more than 200 people were injured.{{cite journal |author=Lo Shiu-hing |title=Aspects of Political Development in Macau |journal=The China Quarterly |volume=120 |date=December 1989 |pages=837–851 |doi=10.1017/S030574100001849X}} On 28 January 1967, the Portuguese government issued a formal apology by means of an "admission of guilt".{{cite book|title=[[Sovereignty at the Edge: Macau & the Question of Chineseness]]|volume=|year=2010|author=Cathryn H. Clayton|publisher=[[Harvard University]] Press|edition=|location=|isbn=978-0-674-03545-4|page=[https://books.google.com/?id=2alTUjb6SX8C&pg=PA48 48]|quote=}} Shortly after Portugal's 1974 [[Carnation Revolution]], which overthrew the [[Estado Novo (Portugal)|Estado Novo dictatorship]], the new government determined it would relinquish all its overseas possessions. In 1976, Lisbon redefined Macau as a "Chinese territory under Portuguese administration" and granted it a large measure of administrative, financial, and economic autonomy. Three years later, Portugal and China agreed to regard Macau as "a Chinese territory under [temporary] Portuguese administration".[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=e61PAQAAMAAJ&q=%22a+Chinese+territory+under+%5Btemporary%5D+Portuguese+administration%22&dq=%22a+Chinese+territory+under+%5Btemporary%5D+Portuguese+administration%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj74pP2iMXQAhUGKMAKHYGHBUgQ6AEIRDAH ''Asian Bulletin''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161126130316/https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=e61PAQAAMAAJ&q=%22a+Chinese+territory+under+%5Btemporary%5D+Portuguese+administration%22&dq=%22a+Chinese+territory+under+%5Btemporary%5D+Portuguese+administration%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj74pP2iMXQAhUGKMAKHYGHBUgQ6AEIRDAH |date=26 November 2016 }}, Volume 10, Issues 7–12, APACL Publications, 1985, p. 46 The Chinese and Portuguese governments commenced negotiations on the question of Macau in June 1986. The two signed the [[Joint Declaration on the Question of Macau|Sino-Portuguese Joint Declaration]] the next year, making Macau one of the [[special administrative regions of China]].[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=cYoHOqC7Yx4C&lpg=PA248&dq=%22a%20Chinese%20territory%20under%20%5Btemporary%5D%20Portuguese%20administration%22%20-IBP&pg=PA248#v=onepage&q&f=true ''Columbia Chronologies of Asian History and Culture''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161126065941/https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=cYoHOqC7Yx4C&lpg=PA248&dq=%22a%20Chinese%20territory%20under%20%5Btemporary%5D%20Portuguese%20administration%22%20-IBP&pg=PA248 |date=26 November 2016 }}, John Bowman, Columbia University Press, 2005, p. 248 ===Transfer of sovereignty and SAR status=== [[File:PLA Enter Macau.jpg|thumb|left|The [[People's Liberation Army]] enters Macau after the transfer of sovereignty on 20 December 1999]] The Chinese government [[Transfer of sovereignty over Macau|assumed formal sovereignty over Macau]] on 20 December 1999 as a [[special administrative regions of China|special administrative region]] (SAR) after over 400 years of Portuguese colonial rule.Macau Yearbook 2007, 519–520. This event also marked the end of the [[Portuguese Empire]] and European colonialism in Asia. The economy since then has continued to prosper with the sustained growth of tourism from [[mainland China]] and the construction of new [[casino]]s.{{cite web|url=http://globaledge.msu.edu/countries/macau/economy|title=Macau: Economy|accessdate=18 January 2014|publisher=Michigan State University|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201193704/http://globaledge.msu.edu/countries/macau/economy|archivedate=1 February 2014|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://e.nikkei.com/e/fr/tnks/Nni20131023D23HH259.htm|title=Macau Casinos Thrive As Landscape Shifts|accessdate=18 January 2014|publisher=Nikkei Asian Review|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131024044715/http://e.nikkei.com/e/fr/tnks/Nni20131023D23HH259.htm|archivedate=24 October 2013|df=dmy-all}} == Government and politics == {{main|Politics of Macau|Legislative Assembly of Macau|Legal system of Macau|Civic and Municipal Affairs Bureau}} [[File:Macau Government Headquarters 01.JPG|thumb|[[Macau Government Headquarters]]]] The Sino-Portuguese Joint Declaration and Macau Basic Law, Macau's constitution, promulgated by China's [[National People's Congress]] in 1993, specify that Macau's social and economic system, lifestyle, rights, and freedoms are to remain unchanged for at least 50 years after the transfer of sovereignty to China in 1999.{{cite web|url=http://www.umac.mo/basiclaw/english/main.html|title=Content of Basic Law of Macau|accessdate=7 January 2008|publisher=University of Macau|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071030094729/http://www.umac.mo/basiclaw/english/main.html|archivedate=30 October 2007|df=dmy-all}} Under the principle of "[[one country, two systems]]", Macau enjoys a high degree of autonomy in all areas except defence and foreign affairs. Macau officials, rather than PRC officials, run Macau through the exercise of separate executive, [[legislative]], and [[judicial]] powers, as well as the right to final adjudication.{{cite web|url=http://www.imprensa.macau.gov.mo/bo/i/1999/leibasica/index_uk.asp#c2 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20010320024207/http://www.imprensa.macau.gov.mo/bo/i/1999/leibasica/index_uk.asp#c2 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=20 March 2001 |title=Basic Law of Macau Chapter II: Relationship between the Central Authorities and the Macau Special Administrative Region |accessdate=3 January 2008 |publisher=Government Printing Bureau }} Macau maintains its own currency (the [[Macanese pataca]]), customs territory, immigration and border controls and police force.{{cite web|url=http://www.imprensa.macau.gov.mo/bo/i/1999/leibasica/index_uk.asp#c5 |title=Basic Law of Macau Chapter V: The Economy |accessdate=3 January 2008 |publisher=Government Printing Bureau |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080105011110/http://www.imprensa.macau.gov.mo/bo/i/1999/leibasica/index_uk.asp |archivedate=5 January 2008 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.imprensa.macau.gov.mo/bo/i/1999/leibasica/index_uk.asp#c7 |title=Basic Law of Macau Chapter VII: External Affairs |accessdate=3 January 2008 |publisher=Government Printing Bureau |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080105011110/http://www.imprensa.macau.gov.mo/bo/i/1999/leibasica/index_uk.asp |archivedate=5 January 2008 |df= }} === Executive === The government in Macau is headed by the [[Chief Executive of Macau]], who is appointed by the central government upon the recommendation of an election committee, whose three hundred members are nominated by corporate and community bodies. The recommendation is made by an election within the committee.{{cite web |url=http://www.imprensa.macau.gov.mo/bo/i/2004/14/lei03_en.asp#c4a32 |title=Election of the Chief Executive |accessdate=5 September 2006 |publisher=Government Printing Bureau |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051108035112/http://www.imprensa.macau.gov.mo/bo/i/2004/14/lei03_en.asp#c4a32 |archivedate=8 November 2005 |df=dmy-all }} The chief executive's cabinet is made up of five policy secretaries and two commissariats and is advised by the [[Executive Council of Macau]], which has between seven and eleven members.{{cite book |year=2007 |title=Macau 2007 Yearbook |publisher=Government Information Bureau of Macau SAR |isbn=978-99937-56-09-5}} [[Edmund Ho]], a community leader and former banker, was the first chief executive of the Macau SAR, replacing [[Vasco Joaquim Rocha Vieira|General Vasco Rocha Vieira]] at midnight on 20 December 1999. [[Fernando Chui]] is the current Chief Executive.{{cite web |url=http://lanzhou.china.com.cn/english/NM-e/105438.htm |accessdate=7 January 2008 |title=Edmund Ho Wins Election for 2nd Term |publisher=Xinhua News Agency |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080521031956/http://lanzhou.china.com.cn/english/NM-e/105438.htm |archivedate=21 May 2008 |df=dmy-all }} The chief executive and the cabinet have their offices in the [[Macau Government Headquarters]], located in the area of [[São Lourenço, Macau|São Lourenço]]. === Legislature === [[File:Assembleia Legislativa.jpg|thumb|[[Legislative Assembly of Macau]]]] The legislative organ of the territory is the [[Legislative Assembly of Macau|Legislative Assembly]], a 33-member body comprising 14 directly elected members, 12 indirectly elected members representing [[Functional constituency (Macau)|functional constituencies]] and seven members appointed by the chief executive.{{cite web|url=http://www.al.gov.mo/en/en.htm#Composition |accessdate=5 September 2006 |title=Introduction of the Legislative Assembly of the Macau Special Administrative Region |publisher=The Legislative Assembly of Macau |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303194636/http://www.al.gov.mo/en/en.htm |archivedate=3 March 2016 |df= }} Any permanent residents at or over 18 years of age are eligible to vote in direct elections.{{cite web |url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/fields/2123.html |accessdate=7 January 2008 |title=List of Suffrage |publisher=CIA – The World Factbook |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080109020202/https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/fields/2123.html |archivedate=9 January 2008 |df=dmy-all }} Indirect election is limited to organizations registered as "corporate voters" and a 300-member election committee drawn from broad regional groupings, municipal organizations, and central government bodies.{{cite web |url=http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/200403/31/eng20040331_139074.shtml |accessdate=7 January 2008 |title=Polls favor indirect vote of Macau's next chief executive |publisher=(Source: Xinhua) People's Daily Online |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080522184955/http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/200403/31/eng20040331_139074.shtml |archivedate=22 May 2008 |df=dmy-all }} In February 2009, the Legislative Assembly passed the [[Macau national security law]] based on [[Hong Kong Basic Law Article 23|a withdrawn security legislation]] previously introduced in Hong Kong.{{cite web|url=http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/90001/90776/90785/6601685.html|title=Macao legislature passes national security bill|publisher=Peopledaily|accessdate=18 September 2009|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110510004036/http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/90001/90776/90785/6601685.html|archivedate=10 May 2011|df=dmy-all}} Democracy advocates feared that the bill's excessively broad scope could lead to abuses, a concern which has been heightened after a number of prominent supporters of democracy in Hong Kong [[Hong Kong Macau cultural exchange|were denied entry]] into Macau in the run-up to the bill's passage.{{cite web|url=http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/country,,,,MAC,4562d8cf2,49a660b913,0.html|title=Macao: Stop the National Security Bill now|publisher=Amnesty International|accessdate=18 September 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110510011736/http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/country,,,,MAC,4562d8cf2,49a660b913,0.html|archivedate=10 May 2011|df=dmy-all}} === Judiciary === {{main|Legal system of Macau}} [[File:EdfDosTribunaisDeSegundaEUltimaInstancias1.jpg|thumb|Seat of the Superior Tribunal of Macau]] The original framework of the legal system, based largely on the [[Law of Portugal]], the Portuguese civil law system, was preserved after 1999. The territory has its own independent judicial system with a [[High Court]] independent of both the local Government and the Central People's Government of the People's Republic of China. Judges are selected by a committee and appointed by the chief executive. Foreign judges may serve on the courts.{{cite web |url=http://www.unesco.org.mo/eng/law/4judicialSystem.html |title=Brief Introduction of Judicial System of Macau SAR |accessdate=5 September 2006 |author=Sam Hou Fai |publisher=UNESCO |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060430035340/http://www.unesco.org.mo/eng/law/4judicialSystem.html |archivedate=30 April 2006}} The judicial organs of the Macau are the [[Politics of Macau|Public Ministry]]; the Courts of First Instance, which are subdivided into the Basic Judicial Court and Administrative Court; the Court of the Second Instance and the [[Court of Final Appeal (Macau)|Court of Final Appeal]].{{cite web |url=https://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/7066.htm |title=Background Note: Macau – Government |publisher=Bureau of East Asian and Pacific Affairs, U.S. Department of State |accessdate=24 May 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070508225846/http://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/7066.htm |archivedate=8 May 2007 |df=dmy-all }} The legal system of Macau is essentially based on the model of [[Law of Portugal|Portuguese law]], and is thus part of the family of continental legal systems ([[Civil law (legal system)|Roman-Germanic]]). From 1987 to 1999, this legal system was completely modernized with a view to the transfer of sovereignty from Macau to the [[People's Republic of China]]. Thus, a number of new laws and codes have been adopted, including the Criminal Code (1995), the Civil Code (1999), the Commercial Code (1999), the Criminal Procedure Code (1996) and the Civil Procedure Code (1999). Following the transition, major reforms in the legal system continued, such as the use of [[Chinese language]] in courts and legislations. From a constitutional point of view, the Macau legal system is characterized by the existence of a text with constitutional force in the Macau SAR, the [[Macau Basic Law|Basic Law of the Macau Special Administrative Region]], promulgated by the [[National People's Congress]] in 1993. As a rule, the national laws of the People's Republic of China do not apply to Macau, except for those expressly indicated in Annex III of the Basic Law. At present, they are eleven and deal with matters not included in the autonomy of the Special Administrative Region, such as national defense and external relations. The gambling sector, being a fundamental economic activity for Macau, is subject to a very developed regulation, thus having a good and developed right of the game. There is no [[death penalty]] or [[life imprisonment]] in Macau, as they are not covered by the Macau Criminal Code. [[File:PSPFM vehicles.jpg|thumb|Macau Police vehicles]] === Military === {{main|People's Liberation Army Macau Garrison}} {{see also|Military of Macau under Portuguese rule|Liaison Office of the Central People's Government in the Macau Special Administrative Region}} Under Portuguese rule, Macau often served as an expeditionary base to [[Japan]] and other regions of East Asia from the 16th century onwards, while maintaining a strong garrison mainly to repel Dutch and mainland Chinese attacks. However, since the [[Anglo-Portuguese Alliance|allied]] [[United Kingdom|British]] settled Hong Kong, the need for a strong military presence in Macau dimmed and it became limited before ceasing in 1974. However, despite having no Portuguese garrison left on the territory, a small security force managed by the local [[Polícia de Segurança Pública|PSP]] was kept, which proved useful with the escalating [[Triad (underground society)|triad]] warfare tensions towards the last decades of Portuguese administration. Also the [[Captain of the Port|Capitania dos Portos]] kept operating a coast guard and the [[Portuguese Armed Forces|Portuguese airforce]] kept airfields active until the opening of [[Macau International Airport]] in the mid-1990s. In 1999, upon handover to the PRC, a substantial [[People's Liberation Army Macau Garrison|garrison of the People's Liberation Army]] was established in the city helping deliver the last blow to the violence perpetrated by the triads, who were weakened by police action and arrests prior to the [[Handover of Macau to China|handover]]. The garrison remains, with a large portion of the forces stationed in neighbouring [[Zhuhai]] as well. According to the Article 14, [[Macau Basic Law]], The Central People's Government shall be responsible for the defense of the Macau Special Administrative Region. And The Government of the Macau SAR shall be responsible for the maintenance of public order in the Region. ===International relations=== {{main|Foreign relations of Macau}} As a [[Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China|special administrative region]] (SAR) of the [[People's Republic of China]] (PRC), Macau's diplomatic relations and [[defense (military)|defence]] are the responsibility of the [[Central People's Government]] of the PRC. Except diplomatic relations and defence, nonetheless, Macau has retained considerable autonomy in all aspects, including economic and commercial relations, customs control. According to Chapter VII of [[basic law of Macau|Macau's basic law]], Macau may, on its own, using the name ''Macau, China'' or ''Macao, China'', maintain and develop relations and conclude and implement agreements with foreign states and regions and relevant [[international organisation]]s in the appropriate fields, including the economic, trade, financial and monetary, shipping, communications, tourism, cultural, science and technology, and sports fields. In addition, Macau can participate in international organizations and conferences not limited to states. The Macau government has maintained offices in [[Lisbon]], [[Taipei]], [[Beijing]] and in [[Brussels]] for the [[European Union]] and [[Geneva]] for the [[World Trade Organization]]. The Special Administrative Region of Macau is member of the World Trade Organization, [[International Monetary Fund]] as well as other international cultural and commercial organizations. ===Administrative divisions=== [[File:Administrative Division of Macau.png|thumb|Administrative divisions of Macau]] Macau is divided into 8 [[Parishes of Macau|parishes]]. {|class="wikitable sortable" ! Parish ! Chinese ! Area
(km2){{cite web|title=Estatístico: Área de solos das freguesias|url=http://www.dscc.gov.mo/ENG/knowledge/geo_statistic.html|publisher=Direcção dos Serviços de Cartografia e Cadastro de Macau|accessdate=27 October 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6AVvTJ0v0?url=http://www.dscc.gov.mo/ENG/knowledge/geo_statistic.html|archivedate=8 September 2012|df=dmy-all}} |- | [[Nossa Senhora de Fátima, Macau|Nossa Senhora de Fátima]] | {{lang|zh-hant|花地瑪堂區}} | 3.2 |- | [[Santo António, Macau|Santo António]] | {{lang|zh-hant|花王堂區}} | 1.1 |- | [[São Lázaro]] | {{lang|zh-hant|望德堂區}} | 0.6 |- | [[São Lourenço, Macau|São Lourenço]] | {{lang|zh-hant|風順堂區}} | 1.0 |- | [[Sé, Macau|Sé]] | {{lang|zh-hant|大堂區}} | 3.4 |- | [[Taipa|Nossa Senhora do Carmo]] | {{lang|zh-hant|嘉模堂區}} | 7.6 |- | [[Cotai]] | {{lang|zh-hant|路氹填海區}} | 5.8 |- | [[Coloane|São Francisco Xavier]] | {{nowrap|{{lang|zh-hant|聖方濟各堂區}}}} | 7.6 |} == Geography == {{main|Geography of Macau}} Macau is situated {{convert|60|km|mi|0}} southwest of Hong Kong and {{convert|145|km|mi|0}} from [[Guangzhou]] of [[Mainland China]]. It also has {{convert|41|km|mi|0}} of coastline, yet only {{convert|310|m|ft|sigfig=2}} of land border with [[Guangdong]] of [[Mainland China]].Macau Yearbook 2007, 475.{{cite web |url=http://www.asiarooms.com/travel-guide/macau/macau-overview/macau-geography.html |title=Macau Geography |accessdate=6 January 2008 |publisher=AsiaRooms.com |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080112081315/http://www.asiarooms.com/travel-guide/macau/macau-overview/macau-geography.html |archivedate=12 January 2008 |df=dmy-all }} It consists of the [[Macau Peninsula]] itself and the islands of [[Taipa]] and [[Coloane]], which are now connected by landfill forming [[Cotai]]. The peninsula is formed by the [[Zhu Jiang]] (Pearl River) [[estuary]] on the east and the [[Xi Jiang]] (West River) on the west. It borders the [[Zhuhai]] [[Special Economic Zone]] in mainland China. The main border crossing between Macau and China is known as the [[Portas do Cerco]] (Barrier Gate) on the Macau side, and the [[Gongbei Port of Entry]] on the Zhuhai side.{{cite web |url=http://www.newsgd.com/citiesandtowns/zhuhai/news/200603030050.htm |title=Zhuhai Gongbei Checkpoint Opens Earlier |accessdate=6 January 2008 |author=Yan |publisher=New Guangdong newsgd |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080519222157/http://www.newsgd.com/citiesandtowns/zhuhai/news/200603030050.htm |archivedate=19 May 2008 |df=dmy-all }} File:Lago Nam Van, Macao, 2013-08-08, DD 06.jpg|Lago Nam Van, Macau File:Vista de los casinos desde el Centro de Ciencia, Macao, 2013-08-08, DD 01.jpg|View of the casinos from Science Center File:Centro de Ciencia, Macao, 2013-08-08, DD 10.jpg|View of [[Taipa]] from [[Macau Science Center|Science Center]] File:Mar Oriental de China entra Taipa y la Península de Macao, Macao, 2013-08-08, DD 01.jpg|East China Sea between Taipa and the Macau Peninsula, Macau File:Macau peninsula.jpg|[[Macau Peninsula]] File:Aerial view of Macau at night.jpg|Aerial view of Macau at night Vistas de Macao, 2013-08-08, DD 02.jpg|View of the old city in Macau with tenement housing in the foreground Macau Peninsula was originally an island, but a connecting [[sandbar]] gradually turned into a narrow [[isthmus]]. Land reclamation in the 17th century transformed Macau into a peninsula with generally flat terrain, though numerous steep hills still mark the original land mass. Alto de Coloane is the highest point in Macau, with an altitude of {{convert|170.6|m|ft|1}}. With a dense [[urbanisation|urban environment]], Macau has no arable land, pastures, forest, or woodland. In 2015, the Chinese government assigned Macau administrative responsibility for {{convert|85|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} of coastal ocean area.{{cite web|title=Macao to administrate 85 square kilometres of waters|url=http://www.gcs.gov.mo/showNews.php?DataUcn=95418&PageLang=E|website=Government Information Bureau of the MSARGovernment Information Bureau of the MSAR|publisher=Government of Macau|accessdate=21 December 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222115647/http://www.gcs.gov.mo/showNews.php?DataUcn=95418&PageLang=E|archivedate=22 December 2015|df=dmy-all}} {{wide image|Macau banner.jpg|1800px|align-cap=center|Macau skyline}} === Climate === Macau has a [[humid subtropical climate]] ([[Köppen climate classification]]: ''Cwa''), despite its low elevation coastal location south of the [[Tropic of Cancer]], with average relative humidity between 75% and 90%.{{cite web |url=http://www.worldtravelguide.net/country/153/climate/Far-East-Asia/Macau.html |title=Macau Climate, Temp, Rainfall and Humidity |accessdate=6 January 2008 |publisher=Nexus Business Media Limited |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071216232707/http://www.worldtravelguide.net/country/153/climate/Far-East-Asia/Macau.html |archivedate=16 December 2007}} Similar to much of South China, seasonal climate is greatly influenced by the [[monsoon]]s, and differences in temperature and humidity between summer and winter are noticeable, though not as great as in mainland China. The average annual temperature of Macau is {{convert|22.7|°C|°F|1}}.{{cite web |url=http://www.smg.gov.mo/www/smg/centenary2/index_four.htm |title=100 years of Macau Climate |accessdate=15 February 2011 |publisher=Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110110060346/http://www.smg.gov.mo/www/smg/centenary2/index_four.htm |archivedate=10 January 2011 |df=dmy-all }} July is the warmest month, the average temperature being {{convert|28.9|°C|°F|1}}. The coolest month is January, with a mean temperature of {{convert|14.5|°C|°F|1}}. Located on China's southern coast, Macau has ample rainfall, with average annual [[precipitation (meteorology)|precipitation]] being {{convert|2120|mm|in|0}}. However, winter is mostly dry due to the influence of the vast [[Siberian High]] affecting much of East Asia. Autumn in Macau, from October to November, is sunny and still pleasantly warm with lower humidity. Winter (December to early March) is generally mild with temperatures above {{convert|13|°C|0}} most of the time, although they can drop below {{convert|8|°C|0}} at times. Humidity starts to increase from late March. Summer is very warm to hot (often rising above {{convert|30|°C|0}} during the day). The hot weather is often followed by heavy rain, thunderstorms and occasional typhoons. margin: 0 1em 1em 0; border: 1px #bbb solid; border-collapse: collapse; font-size: 90%;" |- style="text-align:center; background:salmon;" !colspan=3|Employed population by
occupation 2007{{cite web |url = http://www.dsec.gov.mo//english/indicator/e_ie_indicator_8.html |title = Employed population by occupation |accessdate = 27 December 2007 |publisher = Statistics and Census Service (DSEC) of the Macau Government |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071124192250/http://www.dsec.gov.mo/english/indicator/e_ie_indicator_8.html |archivedate = 24 November 2007}} |- style="text-align: center; background: lightsalmon;" |Occupation|| no.
('000) |- style="text-align: center;" |Senior officials/managers || 14.6 |- style="text-align: center;" |Professionals|| 9.9 |- style="text-align: center;" |Technicians|| 28.1 |- style="text-align: center;" |Clerks|| 83.7 |- style="text-align: center;" |Service & sale workers|| 63.2 |- style="text-align: center;" |Workers in agriculture/fishery|| 0.8 |- style="text-align: center;" |Craft & similar workers|| 33.7 |} Macau's economy is based largely on tourism. Other chief economic activities in Macau are export-geared textile and garment manufacturing, banking and other financial services.Chan, 12–13. The clothing industry provides about three quarters of export earnings, and the gambling, tourism and hospitality industry is estimated to contribute more than 50% of Macau's GDP, and 70% of Macau government revenue. Macau is a founding member of the [[WTO]] and has maintained sound economic and trade relations with more than 120 countries and regions, with [[European Union]] and [[Community of Portuguese Language Countries|Portuguese-speaking countries]] in particular; Macau is also a member of the [[IMF]].{{cite web |url = https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/mc.html |title = CIA the world factbook |accessdate = 15 November 2007 |publisher = CIA the World Factbook – Macau |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071114013759/https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/mc.html |archivedate = 14 November 2007 |df = dmy-all }} The [[World Bank]] classifies Macau as a high income economy{{cite web |url = http://web.worldbank.org/servlets/ECR?contentMDK=20421402&sitePK=239419#High_income |title = Income Group – High Income, World Bank |accessdate=15 November 2007 |publisher = World Bank}} and the GDP per capita of the region in 2006 was US$28,436. After the 1999 [[Transfer of the sovereignty of Macau|Handover]], China eased travel restrictions and visits from the mainland rose rapidly. Together with the liberalization of Macau's gambling industry in 2001, which induced significant investment inflows, the average [[Economic growth|growth rate]] of the economy between 2001 and 2006 was approximately 13.1% annually.{{cite web |url = http://www.amcm.gov.mo/economic_statistics/economic.htm |title = Economic statistics from Monetary Authority of Macau |publisher = AMCM |accessdate = 23 December 2007 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://archive.is/20121219210637/http://www.amcm.gov.mo/economic_statistics/economic.htm |archivedate = 19 December 2012 |df = dmy-all }} In a [[World Tourism Organization]] report of international tourism for 2006, Macau ranked 21st in the number of tourists and 24th in terms of tourism receipts.{{cite web |url=http://unwto.org/facts/eng/pdf/barometer/unwto_barom07_2_en.pdf |title=UNWTO World Tourism Barameter |date=June 2007 |accessdate=16 January 2008 |publisher=World Tourism Organisation (UNWTO) |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726015601/http://unwto.org/facts/eng/pdf/barometer/unwto_barom07_2_en.pdf |archivedate=26 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }} From 9.1 million visitors in 2000, arrivals to Macau has grown to 18.7 million visitors in 2005 and 22 million visitors in 2006, with over 50% of the arrivals coming from mainland China and another 30% from Hong Kong.{{cite web |url = http://www.dsec.gov.mo/index.asp?src=/english/indicator/e_tur_indicator_1.html |title = Visitor arrivals by place of residence |accessdate = 5 September 2006 |publisher = Statistics and Census Service (DSEC) of the Macau Government }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Starting in 1962, the gambling industry had been operated under a government-issued monopoly license by [[Stanley Ho]]'s [[Sociedade de Turismo e Diversões de Macau]]. The monopoly ended in 2002 and several casino owners from [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]] attempted to enter the market. With the opening of the [[Sands Macao]],{{cite web |url = http://www.readybetgo.com/news/sands-Macau-largest--2277.html |title=Sands Macau-is the largest casino in the world |accessdate=24 August 2006 |publisher=Ready Bet Go}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} in 2004 and [[Wynn Macau]] in 2006,{{cite web |url=http://www.casinocitytimes.com/news/article.cfm?contentId=160162 |title=Wynn Fine-Tuning Details at 600-Room Macau Resort |accessdate=5 September 2006 |publisher=Gaming News |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927004745/http://www.casinocitytimes.com/news/article.cfm?contentId=160162 |archivedate=27 September 2007 |df=dmy-all }} gambling revenues from Macau's casinos grew considerably prosperous.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/6083624.stm |title=Macau, a tiny special administrative region of China, appears to have overtaken the famous Las Vegas Strip as the world's top gambling destination |accessdate=25 October 2006 |publisher=BBC News – Business |date=25 October 2006 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061107102719/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/6083624.stm |archivedate=7 November 2006 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web |url=http://www.businessweek.com/investor/content/jun2006/pi20060608_011406.htm |title=Vegas vs. Macau, who will win? Numerous other hotel casinos, including [[Galaxy Macau|Galaxy Cotai Megaresort]], opened in 2011,[http://www.macaudailytimes.com.mo/macau/23050-Galaxy-open-Cotai-resort-May.html Galaxy to open Cotai resort on May 15.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230234232/http://www.macaudailytimes.com.mo/macau/23050-Galaxy-open-Cotai-resort-May.html |date=30 December 2013 }} 11 March 2011 09:06:00 Tiago Azevedo. Macau Daily Times and plans for a $3.9 billion complex that will be known as Lisboa Palace is expected to be completed by 2017.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/26/business/international/macau-rides-high-on-new-round-of-casino-construction.html |last=Wassener |first=Bettina |title=Macau Rides High on New Round of Casino Construction |date=25 March 2014 |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=5 July 2018}} In February 2015, the gambling revenue in Macao fell by 48.6 percent from a year earlier to 19.5 billion [[patacas]] ($2.4 billion), the biggest monthly decline that has ever been recorded. Reasons for this fall of revenue are related to the slowdown that the Chinese economy is having and a corruption crackdown by Chinese officials which has constrained lavish spending.{{cite news|title=Macau Casino Revenue Plunges by Half in February|url=https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2015/03/03/world/asia/ap-as-macau-casino-revenues.html?_r=0|accessdate=5 April 2015|agency=The New York Times|publisher=THE ASSOCIATED PRESS|date=3 March 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150419182249/http://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2015/03/03/world/asia/ap-as-macau-casino-revenues.html?_r=0|archivedate=19 April 2015|df=dmy-all}} In 2002, the Macau government ended the monopoly system and six casino operating concessions and subconcessions are granted to Sociedade de Turismo e Diversões de Macau, [[Wynn Resorts]], [[Las Vegas Sands]], [[Galaxy entertainment|Galaxy Entertainment Group]], the partnership of [[MGM Mirage]] and Pansy Ho (daughter of Stanley Ho), and the partnership of Melco and [[Publishing and Broadcasting Limited]] (PBL).
